awd_titl_txt: International:  Engineering Research and Educational Collaboration on Gallium-Nitride (GaN) Lasers and Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs)
awd_abstract_narration: This project is built upon the existing collaborations between the PIs from the California Polytechnic State University (Cal Poly) in the U.S. and the foreign partners from Peking University (PKU) in China since 2006. Based on their previous work together, this project will focus on: 1) year-round research collaboration; 2) students' summer visit in PKU; and 3) undergraduate student involvement. The proposed research work includes not only GaN LD/LED device level modeling and simulation, but also fabrication, testing, and control system design for the design and implementation of a new class of efficient and intelligent lighting systems. Intellectual merit: This project has a strong research component and novelty, especially in the area of increasing energy conversion efficiency of GaN light emitter devices. Students will perform GaN LD/LED design simulation at Cal Poly, and Cal Poly students will work at PKU in summer to fabricate their designed devices. Broader impacts: This collaboration provides students a valuable opportunity to gain first-hand overseas educational experiences and also helps them to further adapt themselves in a global environment. In fact, students on both sides will obtain a better understanding of foreign cultures and languages.

Summary:

This is an all year round international collaboration, which also has strong educational value and can be a research/educational model for other universities. First of all, the project emphasizes on US students’ oversea summer research experience. Each US student involved in the project spent at least one summer in Beijing to do research with foreign faculty and foreign graduate students. Secondly, during the fall, winter, and spring quarters of each year, the US students in the team continually work on the project which was discussed and established during their summer visit. We used internet to keep the research communication going all year round. Thirdly, throughout the project, we made extra efforts to recruit 4 Cal Poly female students for this project to promote Women-in-Engineering. Finally, students on both sides obtained a better understanding about foreign cultures. What makes cross-cultural work so different is the additional burden students must deal with in terms of language barriers, cultural differences, varying expectations and levels of respect, work styles, and stereo-types. This collaboration helps our students to adapt themselves to a global environment and simultaneously promotes advances in science and technology by engaging them in cutting-edge research.

In the project, we also tried to establish and operate an energy saving LEDs virtual international research/education center. This is a long-term international engineering education and research collaboration program between California Polytechnic State University (USA), Peking University (China), and Tsinghua University (China) on light emitting diode research during the past years. We focused on GaN laser diode research for the first year with PKU; then GaN light emitting diode (LED) research was added during the second year. In 2012, we expanded our interest to organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) and collaborated with Tsinghua University. In summer 2011 to 2013, there are totally 15 Cal Poly students' visits to Beijing, China; all of them studied mainly in PKU. Our current model of operation is shown in Fig. 1. Cal Poly students were grouped with students in China and worked closely on specific research topics. Students from each team can work with professors on both sides. Through this project, students from US and China obtained experience in collaborating with their foreign partners, with awareness of the cultural differences.


 Intellectual merit:

In this project, we studied GaN LD, GaN LED, Solar cell, OLED, and LED control system. Each student in the research team focused on different topic and made progress.  There are total 23 papers published, (listed below):

1) GaN LED top grating design simulation using RCWA method:

  • Jason Lumanlana, et al,  International Conference on Engineering and Applied Science , Beijing China, July 2012.
  • Gabriela Alemana, et al, 13th IEEE International Conference on Nanotechnology, Beijing China, August 2013 .
  • Xiaomin Jin, et al, The 2nd International Conference on Electronics and Optoelectronics, Shenyang, China, July, 2012.

2)   GaN LED top and bottom grating using FDTD simulation:

  • Travis Robinson, et al,  SPIE Photonic West,  San Francisco, CA, January 2014.
  • Ashli Behilla, et al,  SPIE Optical Engineering + Applications, San Diego, California , August  2014.
  • Gabriel  Halpin, et al, SPIE Photonic West, San Francisco, CA, January 2013,.
  • Gabriel Halpin, et al, The 13th IEEE International Conference on Nanotechnology, August 2013, Beijing China.
  • Greg Chavoor, et al, The SPIE Optical Engineering + Applications, San Diego, California, August 2011.
